gettingStarted.title: Getting Started
gettingStarted.instruction: Think of a recent situation where you acted in a way you'd like to change. This could be an argument, an impulsive decision, or any behavior you want to understand better.

tip.title: Tip:
tip.content: Start with a situation that feels manageable to analyze. You can always come back to practice with more challenging situations later.

sections.title: Problem Behavior
sections.instruction: Be specific and objective. What exactly did you do? Avoid judgmental language like 'I was stupid' and stick to observable behaviors.
sections.placeholder: Specifically describe the behavior you want to change

sections.title: Prompting Event
sections.instruction: This is the immediate trigger. What was happening in the moments right before you felt the urge to engage in the problem behavior?
sections.placeholder: What happened right before the urge/action?

sections.title: Vulnerability Factors
sections.instruction: These are things that made you more likely to engage in the problem behavior. Think about physical state, emotional state, or life circumstances.
sections.placeholder: What made you vulnerable? (e.g. poor sleep, stress)

sections.title: Links in the Chain
sections.instruction: What happened between the prompting event and the problem behavior? Include thoughts, feelings, body sensations, and actions in order.
sections.placeholder: List the sequence of thoughts, feelings and actions...

sections.title: Consequences
sections.instruction: What happened as a result of the problem behavior? Include both immediate and delayed consequences, positive and negative.
sections.placeholder: What were the short-term and long-term consequences?
